    Sir, it has been proposed that an Order should be made under the provisions of the Malaysia Act to extend certain provisions of the Federal Merchant Shipping Ordinance, 1952, to Singapore, Sarawak and Sabah to provide for the establishment and maintenance of a Malaysian Shipping Register. It is envisaged that the powers of the Director of Marine of the Federation in relation to the Register should be exercised in Singapore by the Director of Marine, Singapore, but the officer exercising such functions is known in Singapore by the title of Master Attendant.

    There is before the House the Merchant Shipping (Amendment) Bill and one of the amendments provides for the change of the title of the Master Attendant to that of Director of Marine. YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)


2.43 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is nearly two and a half years since that evening in

Column: 140

this House in July 1961 when the Communists broke off from the united front with the nationalist Left in the P.A.P. to form their own front organisations and to fight against and prevent Malaysia.

    We meet today in the first business session of the new Assembly under very different circumstances. The change that has taken place is a basic mutation in the role and jurisdiction of this House. Many of the forms and rituals have remained. But some Members may have noted that the guns did not boom out in salute when His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara arrived in this Chamber to deliver His speech on the 29th of November. It did not, because the Central Government ruled it to be so. They are in control of the Army which includes the two Infantry Regiments of Singapore, and their practice is that no ceremonial salutes will be given to any Governor of Penang or Malacca or the Yang di-Pertuan Negara of Singapore. In a small way, it symbolises a shift in authority.

    So too those Members who were with us in the last Assembly will have noted that the Committee of Supply on the Budget has been reduced from five to three days with their concurrence, as they did not, quite rightly, raise any objections. For the matters to be discussed no longer include a list ranging from Police, Prisons and Army to Civil Aviation, Meteorological Office, Posts and Telecommunications, Audit. These are all now in the jurisdiction of the Central Government. It means, in effect, that ultimate power is now vested in the Parliament of Malaysia, and any political movement or Party that wishes to re-order the state of our society will have to assume authority for all Malaysia.

    I have, Sir, stated on many a previous occasion that there can be no Communist Singapore until there is first a Communist Malaya and that whoever wishes to make Singapore Communist must first capture power in Malaya. Sir, an analysis of the power situation which has existed since 1948 between Singapore and Malaya is now formally translated into the provisions of the

Column: 141

Constitution of Malaysia. Now, there can constitutionally as well as practically be no Communist Singapore until there is first a Communist Government of Malaysia. I think that is a sobering reminder to Members of the Opposition of the magnitude of the obstacles that lie between them and their political ambitions.

    Indeed it is a truth, which has to be faced by whichever political movement that wishes to win authority and the right to reshape the structure of our economy and our society, that we must first win the majority of the number of seats in Parliament, the Parliament of Malaysia, and command a loyalty of the administration and the obedience of the Army and the Police.

    The fact that we have so many matters, including three-quarters of our revenue, still reserved for the State Government does not alter the fact that we are part of Malaysia and our influence in Malaysia will be determined not by the number of seats that Singapore has in Parliament but by the example that she can set for the rest of Malaysia, an example of the possibilities opening up vistas of progress and prosperity which can be more equally shared by all if similar policies were adopted at the centre.

    Our influence over the deliberations of Parliament in the policies of the Central Government has yet to be felt. Much will depend on what happens in the elections in Malaya next year. Everybody concedes that the U.M.N.O. side of the Alliance can and will win a clear majority. But everybody is waiting to see what happens to the vote in the urban areas and in all the main towns in Malaya, for arising out of that vote, some vital decisions will have to be made both by U.M.N.O. leaders and by us in Singapore.

    It is fairly obvious that if it were possible for the M.C.A. to hold the towns in Malaya, then the present structure of the Central Government and the policies it pursues can go on unchanged.

    But if the towns decisively reject all M.C.A. candidates, then there must be a re-appraisal by U.M.N.O. leaders.

Column: 142

They will then have to decide whether they come to terms with the leadership that can command the loyalty of the sophisticated urban population - Chinese, Indians, Eurasians and others - or govern without the partnership of the leadership of the towns. It is when this moment is reached sometime next year that the bits and pieces will fall into their proper places in the Malaysian scene. Thereafter, the facts of life in Malaysia will have to be faced by all of us.

    It is a struggle for authority to remould our society now in the much bigger Malaysian arena, and the outcome of this struggle is final and conclusive.

    The tragedy is that in quite a number of these towns in Malaya there is no coherent constructive alternative. Yet in spite of this, there could be a massive protest vote registered not so much for the Communist manipulated Parties like the Socialist Front, the Labour Party, Party Ra'kyat, but a vote against the present urban representatives and their records.

    But meanwhile let us confine ourselves to the immediate issues in Singapore. In many ways the issues and the position of the Parties are much clearer to everyone. The line that divides the Government and the Opposition is between those who are for Malaysia and our survival in South-East Asia as a separate political entity, and the Barisan Sosialis, a front for the Communists who, for their own selfish ends, have tried to prevent Malaysia, and so prevent merger; and who even now after the creation of Malaysia, are still anti-Malaysia and against the nation.

    Sir, there was a time in October, some six weeks ago, when it looked as though with the creation of Malaysia the Communists would accept its establishment and try to win within. But there are increasing signs that they have decided to continue their anti-Malaysia struggle, even though this means that they are more and more openly identified with outside forces, like the Communist Party in Indonesia, who are out to crush Malaysia. National service they have condemned, and in its place is their pious suggestion that we should beg to

Column: 143

be allowed to live in peace, presumably by abandoning Sabah and Sarawak to their fate. This is the line of treachery and betrayal.

    This is not a line likely to win them popular support. I think they are caught in the intricacies of their own international conspiracy. The line has been laid for them and they have to go on plugging it even if it means losing out in popular support within Malaysia. However, they will try to win support by their exploitation of Chinese educational issues, by the capture and control of trade unions, and manipulation of civic organisations both in the city and in the rural areas. In short, the battle continues on the same old issues over the same old battlefields.

    Sir, the political complexion of this Assembly today reflects more accurately the respective strength of ground feeling and the respective support for competing ideologies. We represent the majority, who prefer the sometimes slower but less drastic progress towards a more equal but a more humane society. They represent the frustrations, hatreds and bitterness of a minority who are ideologically convinced that no government but a Communist one can provide a permanent solution to our economic and social evils. We who have known them for so long know that they are very far from giving up their struggle. Their top leaders never came out in Singapore to be expended. It was only the second rank leaders put in the first line of the open front struggle who have been sacrificed. And the battle will go on relentlessly. We must continue from time to time to spotlight them every now and again when they are up to mischief and to expose them. The Barisan must be shown to be still a Communist front exploiting the name and principles of the democratic system with the purpose of destroying them.

    However, under our new Constitution, this Legislative Chamber will be more concerned with the constructive aspect of government - schools, hospitals, housing, community centres, roads, bridges, drains, parks, and, most important of all, factories. For only the

Column: 144

industrial base which we are now forging can provide a better life for us all.

    In the last ten years of this Chamber so much of the time of this House was preoccupied with the struggle for independence. It was inevitable that we should be preoccupied then with national freedom and the right to determine our own destiny. It was inevitable that in the Opposition years of 1955-59, I myself had taken up the time of this House on the problems of how we were to achieve freedom. But I had hoped that with the attainment of full internal self-government in June 1959 we would have begun to look into the constructive side of government - how to create a better society and provide higher living standards for all, how to create higher social values and civic responsibility. But that was not to be so. For the Communists, it was vital that progress should be minimal. For the more we progress the less likely an eventual Communist victory. And so the destructive debate went on about the Police, Prisons, defence bases and anti-colonialism.

    I have no doubts that they will pursue these issues in Parliament in Kuala Lumpur. But we would be foolish to believe that because we are now independent, therefore the Communists will admit that there is a duty on the part of representatives of the people to construct and not to destroy. They cannot admit that any national construction is possible until all economic ties and military alliances with any Western bloc power have been destroyed. And now since colonialism is no longer there, they have to say that the fight must be against new colonialism, or "neo-colonialism" as they have chosen to call it.

    Sir, the division between this side of the House and the Opposition is deep and abiding. They represent a minority, but a militant and tightly knit minority determined to bring the democratic state down and establish a Communist regime. Sir, we on this side of the House are privileged to have been chosen to represent the majority, the rest of the people who want Malaysia to live in peace and to progress unmolested. We are a Party dedicated to democratic

Column: 145

socialism. But it is our duty to recognise that the only long-term basis on which national unity can be forged and stability ensured is for us to bind all those sectors of society who reject the soul-less creed of a Communist dictatorship as the only answer to our undoubtedly many social evils. And we are proud that in the process we have been able to convince large sectors of the community - from labourers to wealthy merchants and the professional and middle classes -that the long-term answer to the Communist challenge lies in an honest and effective administration, a government whose social and economic policies can bring about an appreciable and a visible equalisation of opportunity.

    We would be breaking faith with the mass of the people who voted for us this time if we did not recognise that we represent, as the governing Party, a broad cross-section of the community. We must recognise further that their aspirations are to have a more equal society through the more difficult process of levelling up and not levelling down. In this city of pushful people, energetic and hard working, largely of immigrant stock, the desire is that there should be more opportunities for everyone to work harder and to do better and increase the size of the national cake as much as, if not more than, the desire to share the cake more equally.

    However, we would be doing a disservice to the country if we misled the people into believing that just because this last time the Communists were defeated they would thereby remain an impotent force. There are already signs of their picking up the bits and pieces left of their organisation wrecked by the disastrous policies they have pursued. And we cannot expect them always to be so accommodating in the next round to continue making false and erroneous assumptions. But however skilful they are, they face this one crucial test: what is their attitude to the constructive side of nation building? In other words, however much they can play up anti-neocolonialism, can they really persuade the people that construction should be

Column: 146

set aside, indefinitely until neo-colonialism has been destroyed?

    Sir, I would like to enumerate the four principal targets of constructive effort in the next five years.

    The first is industrialisation. A climate of confidence exists both in the stability of Malaysia and in the known policies of the Singapore Government. The only factor that could upset this climate of overwhelming confidence is if confrontation were to hot up into a military adventure. This is a factor beyond our control. We can only hope that the major world powers will always have their own interests to preserve to ensure that there is no accidental conflict.

    But there is one important factor within our competence to ensure the success of industrialisation, and that is the supply of skilled efficient workers who are not embroiled in the Communist conspiracy of united front trade unions, who are organised into unions designed to further the interests of workers as such and not exploited for political purposes by united front organisations.

    The second target is housing and the rebuilding of the old city. We plan to build 60,000 housing units in the next five years. We are confident that the target can be achieved in spite of the temporary setback of Indonesian confrontation. And there is every hope that when the 8.7 per cent gap in our national income is recovered in two years and our industries begin to flourish, we may well exceed this target of 60,000 housing units. But the amount by which we will exceed this target depends very largely on the growth of our industries.

    Meanwhile, the first phase of the rebuilding of the central city has begun. Outram Road Gaol is being demolished to house eventually some 7,000 to 10,000 families. And if building by private developers, which is again dependent on our economic progress, keeps increasing at the rate it has done over the last three years, then it is not unlikely that in five years, one-quarter of the old city would have been rebuilt.

    Our third target is education. It is already a near miracle that we can now

Column: 147

afford to have all children in primary schools. Forward planning for construction of schools and the training of teachers will keep up with this ever-increasing demand. Our next target in education is to increase the secondary vocational schools so that children who are more suited to work with their hands and eyes than their minds will not fritter away their years between leaving primary school and getting their first job. And it is essential that we build up a whole army of technicians which a modern industrial society requires.

    Sir, one special problem in education is how to check the nation from being undermined by Communist groups recruiting and training in some Chinese schools and in Nanyang University. In Nanyang University the Communists may confuse some people into believing that action meant to restrict their conspiracy is a violation of some sacred principle.

    The Nanyang University Council has hitherto spurned every Government grant to help it raise its standards and put its organisation into shape, largely because the Communists have been able to manipulate some leaders of the Chinese merchant community who have pretensions to greatness, and perhaps to inherit the mantle of another Chinese patriot like the late Mr Tan Kah Kee.

    In Nanyang University with their financial autonomy leaving them in an academic morass, a situation is developing which, if left unchecked within five years, will make it more a University of Yenan than of Nanyang with young pro-Communist graduates and student leaders manipulating the entire governing Council of Nanyang University. Professors and lecturers on year-to-year contracts renewable at will by the Council cannot have economic security, let alone academic freedom. Indeed, the problem of Nanyang can never be resolved until the political abuse the Communists make of it is exposed and stopped. Only a few days ago, the Communists manipulated the Nanyang University Students' Union which issued a statement declaring that the University Council should discontinue

Column: 148

discussions with the Government on aid and reorganisation and refuse any financial aid unless given unconditionally and without supervision.

    Sir, it is the duty of the Government to raise academic standards in Nanyang University and to give it as much assistance as it gives to the University of Singapore. But it is also the duty of the Government to see that none of this money is allowed to be expended on strengthening the intellectual cadre of the Communist Party of Malaya. And it is our duty to see that this does not take place, whether it is in Nanyang University or, for that matter, in the University of Singapore.

    We must be satisfied that the authority and discipline of the academic staff and of a proper governing council of responsible people comprising the founders of Nanyang University from the various States of Malaya, the Senate, and the Government that provides the funds, is not manipulated and controlled by the Communists. And Members will agree that it is not the business of our Government to give money to help train more Communist cadres to destroy the democratic State. But we must deal with this problem as delicately as the sensitiveness of the problem requires. But in the end the truth will be established, that there is a state of affairs in which a small group of militant Chinese Communists from Chinese Middle Schools exploiting the egoism of some merchant millionaires with pretensions to fame and greatness have established their control over the University. When a professor can be asked to explain why certain students fail, then academic freedom has not just been destroyed. Near anarchy has set in.

    Sir, the fourth target is the raising of social standards. By social standards I do not mean only an increase in our social and cultural amenities, however important they are - unemployment benefits, sickness benefits, scholarships and bursaries to secondary schools and universities, community centres, television, or the National Theatre. I wish to emphasise higher standards of public and social conduct. This can be brought

Column: 149

about by a sustained process of education.

    It was inevitable that with new forms of popular and representative government, hawkers, squatters and other social problems increase. But slowly as social standards and civic consciousness correspondingly increase, hawkers for instance begin to understand that they must stay out of the main traffic routes and that they must for their own sake maintain certain standards of cleanliness and hygiene. Litter, rubbish, flies and mosquitoes are not only the job of the Health Ministry and the workers in the Cleansing Department, but the social responsibility of all.

    We are realists enough to know that in trying to achieve these four targets which I have sketched in broad outlines we must anticipate that the Barisan Sosialis and their Communist front organisations will become more and more skilful in their tactics to obstruct and prevent Singapore's success. In thwarting industrialisation, they can create unrest in labour unions and a sense of insecurity to prospective investors.

    We know that they will also become more skilful in camouflaging their tactics of blocking the clearance of sites for housing, schools, clinics and other development plans.

    Sir, the stage has been set for the next five years. We can and we will succeed. The Constitution and responsibilities of this Assembly have been changed, if anything, for the better. Whilst we as a State Assembly may not have so many matters to look after, we have enough of the constructive side to make our sittings useful occasions when progress can be reviewed and faults remedied. It would be useful at these sittings if criticism of our shortcomings either in policy or implementation were aired not only by the Opposition but also by our Back benchers. It can serve a useful purpose in bringing public attention to how things are done, how they can be done better, or why an apparent ineptitude has in fact a rational and valid explanation.

Column: 150



    You may have noticed, Mr Speaker, Sir, that since our first sitting in October the Barisan Sosialis, through its Chairman, has issued a statement in which they clearly expressed their intention to downgrade the value of this Chamber. No doubt partly as a result of his unprofitable effort in the last Assembly, the Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis, the former Member for Queenstown, has stated that what is more important is what they do outside and not inside the Legislative Assembly and Parliament. Obviously they have come to realise that people were not impressed with the marathon speeches and futile debates we had in the last Assembly, and quite rightly so. But I believe that this Chamber can serve a useful function to spotlight the hopes and aspirations of the people, to underline the duties of the Government, to point out where it can do more, and finally to bring about a greater understanding of our problems and to improve our effort to build a better Singapore.

    We must never be afraid of departing from accepted and habitual practice either in this Chamber or outside. And it is for this reason that I invite our own Back benchers to criticise the Government in this Chamber for what they consider to be shortcomings, even though this may not be the practice elsewhere. For all of us in this Chamber must realise that the mental attitudes and responses of the mass of the people outside this Chamber are very different from those of the people who elect representatives to the House of Commons in Britain.

    We have gathered valuable experience from our difficulties over the last ten years. To ensure that the democratic system prevails, we must not only ensure that there is an honest and effective Government that produces results. What is more important is that we must also ensure that it is able to keep in touch with the mass of the people, to produce those results in a form and manner the people generally consider desirable, and to prevent the Communists from distorting the success of

Column: 151

the Government or subverting public loyalties by pressure and manipulation.

    In the next five years, Members will see the growth in my office of a special department which will help to create and build up a whole series of grass-root organisations in every village, in every street, and in every major community. All those active in the interests of their fellow citizens can find rewarding work and recognition in Citizens' Consultative Committees. For in the end not only must we succeed in making Singapore a better place, but we must also succeed in building up an organisational structure within the country that can help strengthen the links between the people and their Government so that the best that can be done will be done in their interests. Only in this way can we ensure stability and progress towards a more enlightened and healthy society.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to: -

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government on the 29th November, 1963.".

3.23 p.m.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech starts with the opening remarks of "a new chapter in the history of our people". It is indeed a new chapter, not of so-called independence -because to the people of Singapore, the P.A.P. merger merely means a change of masters - but of Fascist repressions carried out by imperialist agents and stooges against political opponents and against anti-colonial stalwarts; of Fascist violations of the basic democratic rights and freedoms of the people, of Fascist brutal assaults by fully armed police on workers who carry out a peaceful strike in defence of their basic right of association; of arbitrary arrests and detentions without charge or trial; of fresh attempts by neo-colonialism to frustrate the hopes and aspirations of

Column: 152

the people; and of fresh attempts by self-seeking politicians to mislead and deceive the people.

    The new chapter did not start on 16th September. It started long before Malaysia Day. It had started when plans were being completed to impose neo-colonialist Malaysia on the people. British imperialism had resorted to open military suppression of the national uprising in Brunei on 8th December, 1962. Soon after, there followed arbitrary arrests and detention of those uncompromisingly opposed to Malaysia, first in Sarawak in December 1962 and then in Singapore in February 1963.

    In Singapore, because of British backing, the P.A.P. stooges gave free rein to their Fascist tendencies. They proceeded step by step to violate all the basic democratic rights and freedoms of the people.

    Detainees were given inhuman and barbaric treatment of prolonged solitary confinement. Even Assemblymen were arbitrarily arrested on unfounded charges and unceremoniously deprived of their basic human rights. So-called criminal charges were magnified and distorted out of all proportion to suit the evil designs of the P.A.P. When the P.A.P. began preparing for a snap general election, the Barisan was denied even its right as a political Party to hold open air rallies, and the funds of S.A.T.U. unions were frozen on the whimsical excuse that their union members had booed the Prime Minister at a mass rally!

    But with the official proclamation of Malaysia, when sovereignty over Singapore, Sarawak and Sabah was handed over by the United Kingdom Government to the Federation Government, the stage was finally set for yet further repressive measures against political opponents and progressive organisations and individuals in Singapore.

    I do not need to remind the House of what is still fresh in the minds of all in Singapore. The action to revoke the citizenship of Mr Tan Lark Sye; the arrest of Nanyang students, graduates and Barisan candidates; the sudden banning without warning of five rural and hawkers' organisations; the October arrests of trade union leaders and Barisan

Column: 153

Assemblymen; the brutal assault on workers carrying out a peaceful protest strike in defence of their right to join unions of their own choice; the banning of seven large unions of the S.A.T.U. group; the Government's refusal to register S.A.T.U. after two years of de facto recognition by the Government locally and by other world organisations internationally; the breaking of the lawful strike at the Naval Base, etc. All this bears testimony to the Fascist, pro-colonialist and pro-imperialist nature of the P.A.P. this that there will be industrial success and prosperity for the people. In fact, it is clear that with the present dependence on foreign investments, there will be no genuine prosperity for the vast majority of the people of Singapore.

Column: 156

multiplyer effects of Malaysia and confrontation (as it undoubtedly will decline) then the blame is not the P.A.P.'s but the Central Government's!

    Not unexpectedly while the P.A.P. tries to give a picture of growth and prosperity to sidetrack the people's attention from loss of trade, business and employment, it has completely forgotten to mention the supposed avowed objectives of the old P.A.P. - namely, the fight for a more equal and just society.     We in the Barisan have consistently fought for the basic rights and interests of the people. We fight for the oppressed and exploited, the underprivileged and downtrodden. We shall do our best to safeguard their interests, and we shall continue to struggle for justice, equality, democracy, peace and freedom for the people.

Column: 158



    The P.A.P. always uses the Communist bogey to frighten and intimidate the people. And indeed because of its control of the State propaganda apparatus, it has to a certain extent succeeded. But however the P.A.P. may care to play on the theme of the Communist bogey, with the hope of isolating the Barisan and gaining support for itself, it cannot cover up the fact that "poverty in the midst of plenty and unemployment in the face of affluence" are urgent problems which have to be faced, tackled and resolved. Labelling the Barisan pro-Communist simply because we want to help solve these basic problems, cannot deceive the people for any length of time. P.A.P. lies might deceive some of the people all the time, and all the people some of the time. But they cannot deceive all the people all the time. P.A.P. lies will all be exposed. Truth will out and truth will triumph.

    Let me now come to some of the other pro-colonial policies of the P.A.P. I will leave the subject of confrontation and its effects on the economy of Singapore to be debated later when we come to the debate on the Budget statement on Wednesday. But before I go further, let me first remind the House that the financial arrangements under the Malaysia Agreement have literally robbed Singapore of a huge chunk of its revenue. We pay the Federation Government $117 million outright. In addition, we pay for developments of Federal departments in Singapore ($9.5 million) as well as the annually recurrent expenditure of Statecum-Federal departments ($15 million approximately).

    If we add the $30 million so-called loan to the Borneo territories, then the sum given away by Singapore to the Federation comes to about $170 million! $170 million of our money given away! If this money were truly used for construction and development, at least we would be consoled by the fact that our money was put to good use. But it is clear that most of our money will not be spent on construction and development, but on the expansion of armed forces and for the suppression of the national liberation struggle in Borneo!

Column: 159

This is not the way how our money should be spent. Expenditure on armed expansion will only benefit the big arms industries in the United Kingdom and the U.S.A. Our Party had repeatedly warned against this during the debate on the Malaysia Agreement! Now all can see that what the Barisan has all along said is 100 per cent correct. The P.A.P. must be condemned for having signed away all this money of the people of Singapore!

    Now I come to the other pro-colonial policies of the P.A.P.

    In our multi-national State, it is important that genuine equal treatment is given to the four streams of education. Unfortunately the past record of the P.A.P. has shown that it merely pays lip service to its so-called equal treatment of the four streams of education. In actual fact, the P.A.P. lays all emphasis on English education and neglects the rest. Clear evidence of this can be seen in the disproportionately large number of English schools built as against schools for other language streams; and in the large number of students in English, as against Malay and Indian and Chinese schools.

    It is foolish of Government to try to put the blame for the great disparity between the number of students joining English schools and that joining Chinese schools, on the parents themselves and on so-called agitation and unrest in Chinese schools.

    This naive P.A.P. explanation will not hide the evident P.A.P. discrimination against the Chinese language. Neither does the sacking of the inefficient ex-Minister absolve the P.A.P. as a whole from blame. Nor the report that the Prime Minister now suddenly believes in primary education first in the mother tongue.

    That the P.A.P. Government has discriminated against Nanyang University is of course a well-known fact. $8.5 million annual aid is given to the University of Singapore but not a single cent of aid has so far been given to Nantah. Neither have Nantah degrees been recognised nor the graduates been given the same pay and job opportunities.

Column: 160



    No amount of P.A.P. slogan-shouting can deceive the people of Singapore. The fact remains that there is no equal treatment for the four streams of education. It is clear that the P.A.P. education policy is to ultimately "anglicise" all language streams, under cover of so-called "integration".

    As regards the national language, we hope that the proposed intensification of the teaching of the Malay language this time will not turn out to be yet another P.A.P. stunt.

The open and unashamed pressure put on the University of Singapore Council to compel the resignation of Dr Sreenivasan, ex-Vice-Chancellor of the University of Singapore, has opened the eyes of many people in Malaya. All can now see P.A.P. machinations.

The same untenable excuses are now used by the P.A.P. to gain absolute control over the two universities in Singapore. The P.A.P. is bent on a rampage of witch-hunt and Macarthyism in Singapore.

We ask the P.A.P. not to further violate the democratic rights of the people. The seats of learning in Singapore should be granted their university autonomy and academic freedom, and the Government should take steps to ensure this respect for autonomy and academic freedom in the universities of our country.

Column: 161

soon be terminated. We warn the Government that such victimisation and reign of terror must be stopped. P.A.P. politics should not be introduced into schools under the guise of anti-Communism.

    The P.A.P. still shouts autonomy in education. Have not all the recent events proved that what the Barisan has been saying all along is correct - that education autonomy is now totally bankrupt?

    The manner in which the Government has handled the cholera epidemic is deplorable. Choked and unswept drains have caused a great increase in the population of flies and mosquitoes. Diseases like malaria, long unheard of in Singapore, are once again making their reappearance. The danger to health must have been obvious to all. Yet the P.A.P. has been so busy with its anti-Communism crusade that it does not see, or does not want to see, such dangers to the health of Singapore. The result is that a one-time clean Singapore is now turned into a cholera infected port. The number of cholera cases so far confirmed is 23 with two deaths. But the number of cases that are undiagnosed or unconfirmed must be much higher. Daily reports of new cases are still coming in.

    The question is: why has the public health situation in Singapore been so neglected to such a serious extent? Why were there no proper, adequate and timely precautions and preparations made by the Government to inform the people of the serious danger of cholera and so protect them against this disease?

    It cannot be said that the disease was isolated and well under control. No! The disease was rapidly spreading and cholera cases were found in widely separated districts all over the island. The danger of a quick spread of the disease must have been well understood. Yet no action was taken by the P.A.P. Government to quickly isolate, limit and control the disease. No advice was given

Column: 162

to the people to get inoculations as quickly as possible. And the Government made no provisions to start mass inoculations for the people until the dangerous infection had spread far and wide. With such a dangerous infectious disease like cholera, the confirmed diagnosis of two cases is sufficient to warrant the description of the disease situation as epidemic. Yet the people were not informed of the seriousness of the situation until there were 10 confirmed cases.

    Why this P.A.P. "don't-care-less" attitude? Before the general elections when only one single case of cholera appeared in Potong Pasir following the epidemic in Malacca, the Government quickly got down to the job of mass inoculations. Of course, this was meant to show how efficient a government the P.A.P. was. The P.A.P. had hoped to buy votes. This time, after the elections the Government has acted with indifference to the public health situation of Singapore. Almost as if it does not matter! Why such indifference this time? Is it not because the elections are over and the P.A.P. has already formed the Government?

    The P.A.P. must be condemned for its criminal negligence in the handling of the cholera epidemic. If earlier and more energetic action had been taken by the Government, there might not have been so many cholera cases today, and the two deaths might have been prevented. For the Minister to go round the clinics watching inoculations after the damage has been done will not redeem the P.A.P. in the eyes of the people for its gross negligence.

    The P.A.P. has always boasted of its flats and housing and P.A.P. Ministers have received medals and praise from the P.A.P. Government for so-called P.A.P. achievements. It is a matter of the P.A.P. praising the P.A.P. What are the facts? Out of the thousands of housing units built, how many of them are low-cost housing units that the poor people can afford? Column: 163

unoccupied for months and months, in spite of special inducements to would-be tenants.

The great inconvenience to the people might still be somewhat excused because the prolonged drought at one time was not within the control of human endeavour. But today's water shortage has come about largely as a result of P.A.P. incompetence. The P.A.P. must be fully responsible for its failure to pursue vigorously the Johore River project in the last few years. And now as a result of P.A.P. incompetence the people of Singapore not only suffer from the inconvenience of water rationing, but also from the grave dangers of a cholera epidemic.

There is no necessity to borrow from the World Bank. The P.A.P. has already mortgaged all the property of the Public Utilities Board - property belonging to the people of Singapore - to the World Bank on most humiliating terms. The P.A.P. should not repeat the same humiliating mistake. If we can afford to

Column: 164

give loans to the Borneo territories, free of interest, then we certainly can afford to implement the Johore River project on our own steam.

The freezing of funds of the workers, the banning of their unions, the breaking of their lawful strikes, the arbitrary arrest of their trade union leaders - this is what the P.A.P. labour policy means to the workers. Government uses the power of the State to impose its so-called industrial peace on the workers with justice for the employers

Column: 165

and its imperial masters, with oppression and injustice for the workers. That is the meaning of the P.A.P. slogan, and more and more workers are daily awakening to this P.A.P. deception.

The P.A.P. had boasted of its Four-Year Plan, but many of its development plans have been completely forgotten. For example, the Singapore River improvement project and developments in the hospitals, etc. are now set aside. Only a small fraction of the funds provided has been spent on rural development, and so on. The large surpluses year after year of P.A.P. office have come about very largely as a result of P.A.P. inefficiency and under-expenditure on development projects all round. No amount of P.A.P. propaganda to the contrary will be able to hide these facts.

    Today the P.A.P. is still shouting out its successes. Meanwhile the unemployment problem, already acute as it is, is fast becoming more and more acute with each passing day. How does the P.A.P. intend to resolve this grave crisis in the economy of Singapore?

    For selfish reasons the P.A.P. has helped to impose Malaysia on the people, bringing with it Indonesian confrontation and great hardships for the people of Singapore and South-East Asia. The newspapers headline Indonesia as "Hungerland". But on the Malaysia side, Singapore bears the brunt of Indonesian confrontation. Out of a loss of $1,325 million worth of trade for the whole of Malaya in 1962, Singapore's share of the loss amounted to $1,100 million, i.e. more than 80 per cent of

Column: 166

the total loss. Singapore therefore has a special vested interest in the ending of Indonesian confrontation. The living of the vast majority of the people of Singapore depends on it. Hence the need and urgency of our amendment.

    It may be argued that the amendment is in the field of foreign affairs which is under the control of the Central Government and that the Singapore Government has no jurisdiction over such matters. The speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara states that [col. 117 of Hansard, 29th November, 19631:

    `It is policy settled by a Government which commands a majority of the Members of Parliament in Kuala Lumpur that will decide our fate...'.

It may also be argued that Singapore has only 15 Members in a Parliament of 159, and that therefore the influence of these 15 M.P.s is totally inadequate for changing the policy of the Central Government.

    All this is true. We had pointed out all this long ago during the merger debate, and this is one of the reasons why we opposed the P.A.P. merger arrangements, which have already put the neck of Singapore into the noose held by the Federation Government. We must not forget this. We must not forget also that it was the P.A.P. that had actively promoted the formation of Malaysia. And it was the P.A.P. that had insisted, in spite of the glaring injustice and inequality of second-class citizenship and disproportional representation, that its merger terms were fair and reasonable. Morever, for the past two years the P.A.P. has shouted that Malaysia will bring stability, peace and prosperity to the people of Singapore.

    For all these reasons the P.A.P. must bear its full share of responsibility for the economic crisis in Singapore today. The P.A.P. itself has brought about the present sufferings and hardships for the people. It is now the P.A.P.'s bounden duty to help remove the root cause of all such sufferings and hardships.

    It may also be argued that the Barisan Sosialis M.P.s themselves could move a motion to so persuade the Central Government to change its policy and start negotiating with the Indonesian

Column: 167

Government to resolve all existing differences to our mutual benefit and so bring peace and prosperity to South-East Asia.

    But we tell the P.A.P.: it is the P.A.P.'s responsibility to rectify its own mistakes and it might yet redeem itself in the eyes of the people. In normal times it would already have been the duty and responsibility of the Singapore Government to approach the Central Government on matters of State and national interest on behalf of the people of Singapore. These are not normal times. Now the vital interests of the people of Singapore are at stake. Therefore, it becomes the double duty and responsibility of the Singapore Government to raise matters with the Central Government, either on a Government-to-Government level, or even as part of the people's representatives from Singapore in the Central Parliament.

    Confrontation is a serious affair. It has affected not just 8.7 per cent of our economy, and not just 8,200 people as the P.A.P. would like us to believe. The trade loss is at least 16-20 per cent of the total trade of Singapore. The number of people who have lost their jobs and livelihood directly as a result of confrontation must be between 20,000 and 30,000. The number of people indirectly affected as a result of the multiplyer effects must certainly include almost every person in Singapore.

    We must remember too that it is Malaysia that has given rise to Indonesian confrontation. There is already sufficient international tension as a result of rupture of diplomatic relations between the Philippines and Indonesia on the one side and Malaysia on the other. Jingoism and the burning of effigies of leaders of neighbouring countries in order to arouse the so-called patriotic sentiments of the people, will only further increase this international tension. If we openly make preparations for war, first by man-power registration and later by mobilisation and conscription, it will only further aggravate the situation. It might even lead to explosive incidents which may well precipitate our country into a hot war. This is a thing which we must avoid under all circumstances.

Column: 168



    We must remain ever vigilant against foreign imperialist machinations that try to involve the people in the region into fighting against each other. The neo-colonialists and imperialists want to divide our unity and oar strength so that they may continue their policy of divide and rule. If the people go to war, they would merely fall into the imperialist trap. Moreover, the people will not benefit from war, as what follows can only be sufferings and hardships for all. Those who will benefit are the foreign arms industries and the imperialists who want to oppress and exploit us. It is not war but peace that the people want in South-East Asia. And it is peace that we must help to safeguard and defend.

We must get rid of this foreign interference.

    Curiously even Mr Arthur Bottomley, an admirer of the P.A.P., also accepts the principle that it is a good thing to get the three countries together in order "to call a halt to the trouble". This was reported in the Straits Times of 7th December, 1963.

    Therefore, we must do our best to persuade the Federation Government to go to the conference table and negotiate with the Philippines and Indonesia.

    The interests of the people demand that we prevent the present friction from developing further into open conflict and war with Indonesia. Only peace will bring happiness and prosperity to the people. So let all of us in Singapore make our full contribution to the defence of peace in the region.

    We are elected representatives of Singapore, and our primary duties and responsibilities are to the people of Singapore. But we also have our duty and

Column: 169

responsibility to the people of the Federation, the Borneo territories and of the whole of South-East Asia. We hope that all Members of the House will put the interests of the people above party politics and everything else, fully support our amendment, and urge the Government to take immediate steps to persuade the Central Government to get rid of foreign interference, go to the conference table, negotiate with the Indonesian Government, and resolve all existing differences amicably to our mutual benefit, and so help to bring stability, peace and prosperity in South-East Asia.

In

every University Week organised by the Nanyang University Students' Union, a lot of spectators and members of the public attend the exhibition and take part in the activities. Column: 189

the under-graduates, show that the Central Government is unreasonable and barbaric towards Nanyang University. Is the Singapore Government collaborating in these actions of the Central Government?

    The Minister for Labour talked about the Barisan Sosialis Members in this House. have not tried to do so. Has the Central Government adopted this peaceful means or is it stepping up the supply of armaments to launch a hot war to deal with confrontation? our port to good use, we will be able to solve our problems of livelihood and the people of Singapore will then be able to enjoy the same comforts as are enjoyed by the Ministers. Column: 193

their houses had been devastated by fire and all their personal belongings lost, they have to pay higher rentals if they want to stay in Housing Board flats. Do the P.A.P. agree to the action taken by the Central Government or do they support the workers?

trade union leaders, we are of the opinion that the P.A.P. will make use of the N.T.U.C., which is a stooge of the P.A.P., and make use of the Adult Education Board under the control of Mr Devan Nair to deceive and to manipulate the working masses. present economic situation is the result of a colonial economic system inherited by the P.A.P. shattered to pieces, because the majority of the members of the defunct unions do not allow themselves to fall into their trap. Column: 199

unions that are truly representative of the workers' interests have popular support from the working class, because they seek to improve the lot of the workers in general. In other words, they are trying to deceive the workers into believing that by keeping quiet they will be able to have a better lot in future, that it is not necessary for the workers to go on strike to get better terms of service. measures and proposed policies the Singapore workers will be able to lead a decent life, but because the P.A.P. is trying to appease the foreign capitalists, the lot of the workers in Singapore will not be improved; in fact it will deteriorate as more money is being taken away by the foreign capitalists and more and more workers will have to work under worse working conditions with less wages.

in general. Who have assaulted the workers on strike? Who have sold away the interests of the workers? Who have taken the leaders of the workers to prison? And who are actually enjoying life now? of the people who are ignorant of whether who are supporting whom, whether the British bases support our people or we, the people, support the British bases here. Column: 204

In order not to let this point pass away, I find it necessary to repeat what the Minister for Finance, Dr Goh Keng Swee, said on it during his broadcast. He said his view and impression of the trade unions supported by the workers was that they supported only the interest of certain sections of the people. How can you ask the organisation not to seek to improve the lot and the working conditions of the members belonging to it? Of course, people like the P.A.P. Ministers are not satisfied, although they are using their positions in the State to protect their interest. They are not contented with this.
